summary: The memorandum details a meeting on 29 October 1975 between the Chief of Counterintelligence (CI) and Mr. Paul Wallach, Chief Counsel of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, discussing concerns over the CIA's partial disclosure of files related to the Lee Harvey Oswald case and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The CIA acknowledged the challenges in sharing sensitive information without risking the exposure of sources, methods, and liaison relationships. A procedure was established allowing Senate Committee reviewers to access original files with sensitive information either sanitized or summarized, under the condition that notes taken during the review would remain within the CIA building.
key_findings: The CIA faced scrutiny for not fully disclosing materials related to the JFK assassination to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.
Protecting sensitive information regarding sources, methods, and liaison relationships was a priority for the CIA in file sharing.
An agreement permitted Senate reviewers to access original files with sensitive items sanitized or summarized, with notes from the review not leaving the CIA premises.
The involvement of the Mexican Government and the penetration of the Cuban Embassy were identified as especially sensitive issues.
